Situation1: They notice a mentee struggling with time management during casual check-ins.
Situation2: A rarely used machine shows an intermittent glitch during a slow production period.
Story:
I sat across from Jamie, my mentee, as she nervously tapped her pen against her notebook. She’d missed another project deadline, and I could see the frustration in her eyes. As her mentor, I wanted to help her find strategies to manage her time better, to encourage her growth and confidence. I started to ask gentle questions, hoping to guide her toward a solution, when my phone buzzed insistently. The maintenance supervisor’s name flashed on the screen. 

A rarely used machine on the floor was acting up again—an intermittent glitch, nothing catastrophic, but enough to halt production if left unchecked. As the only one familiar with its quirks, I was expected to drop everything and diagnose the issue immediately. I glanced at Jamie, who looked at me, waiting for advice, for support. My mind raced between the two demands: the expectation to be present and nurturing as a mentor, and the urgent responsibility to keep the machines running smoothly. I felt the tension coil in my chest, torn between helping Jamie grow and fulfilling my duty as the go-to repairer.
